ExxonMobil Beaumont Chemical Plant                                                                                                                               Risk Management Plan                                                                                                                                                           Executive Summary

Outline
1.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
2.	REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
3.	GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 
4.	CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
5.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
6.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
7.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

1.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
ExxonMobil is committed to conducting business in a manner that is compatible with the environmental and economic needs of the communities in which we operate, and that protects the safety, health and security of our employees, those involved in our operations, our customers and the public. These commitments are documented in our safety, health, environmental, product safety, and security policies. These policies are put into practice through a disciplined management framework called the Operations Integrity Management System (OIMS).

ExxonMobil's OIMS framework establishes common worldwide expectations for controlling operations integrity risks inherent in its businesses. Operations integrity addresses all aspects of ExxonMobil's business, including security, that can impact safety, health and environmental performance.
The 11 OIMS elements are:
1. Leading, Managing, and Driving Performance
2. Identifying, Assessing, Mitigating and Accepting Risk
3. Designing, Constructing and Preparing Assets (Facilities) for Start Up
4. Providing Information Needed for Asset Construction, Operation and Maintenance
5. Selecting, Training, Engaging and Enabling People
6. Operating and Maintaining Assets
7. Managing Changes
8. Selecting and Engaging with Third-Party Providers
9. Learni

ng From Operating Experience and Incidents
10. Preparing for Emergencies and Managing Potential Risk to the Community
11. Assessing and Driving Effectiveness

By effectively managing the procedures, technology, and personnel interfaces that produce excellence in our operations, we minimize risks and thus effectively manage and minimize the impact of process related incidents.

The ExxonMobil Beaumont Chemical Plant (BMCP) has an ongoing accident prevention program and detailed emergency response plan that involves the participation of local fire, rescue and hospital facilities. BMCP is certified as a U. S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) STAR Work Site for complying with the most stringent health and safety standards set by OSHA. Our participation as a STAR facility in the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) since 1984. In November 2022, we were awarded our 11th STAR and are the longest continuous STAR site in OSHA Region VI. We are listed by OSHA as a "STAR of Excellence."

BMCP, in addition to complying with applicable environmental laws and regulations, is committed to minimizing overall emissions and waste generation from operations wherever technically and economically feasible. This is in alignment with ExxonMobil's commitment to safeguarding and protecting the physical environment.

BMCP maintains a policy to be a good business partner and a safe and conscientious community member who operates the facility in full compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.

2.	REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED 
BMCP in Beaumont, Texas manufactures commodity building block chemicals for further refinement into plastics and chemical derivatives, as well as synthetic lube oils. BMCP handles or manufactures hydrogen, methane, ethane, ethylene, acetylene, propane, propylene, isobutane, 2-methylpropene, butane, butene, crude butadiene, pentane, pentene, and isopentane as materials or RMP-regulated flammable mixtures. Boron trifluoride is used for synth

etic lube processes.  We recently improved our water treatment facilities, removing chlorine from BMCP facilities.  BMCP is organized into three business units: Olefins, Aromatics & Utilities, and Catalyst & Synthetics.  The RMP-covered processes per the criteria in 40 CFR Part 68 are located within the Olefins, Aromatics, and Catalyst & Synthetics business units. Out of the nine (9) RMP processes, eight (8) processes handle regulated flammable substances and mixtures, and one (1) process handles Boron Trifluoride.
The facility occupies 58 acres built along the banks of the Neches River. 

3.	GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 
BMCP has developed effective programs to comply with the industry's most stringent environmental, health, and safety standards, including the American Chemistry Council's mandatory Responsible Care Program, OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).

Additionally, BMCP was the first in the nation to have all its facilities certified as STAR facilities in OSHA's VPP. Facilities in the STAR program are required to demonstrate exemplary safety performance and agree to work cooperatively with OSHA to serve as an example for the industry.  They are audited by OSHA for compliance every few years. Heritage sites in BMCP were among the first facilities in the nation to earn the prestigious STAR recognition and have maintained it through ten OSHA inspections over a 41-year period.

BMCP takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  The process safety management systems align with our OIMS elements to address each of the essential features of successful accident prevention programs including:

Employee participation is covered in Elements 1, 2, and 5
Process safety information is covered in Element 3 and 4
Process hazard analysis is covered in Element 2
Incident investigation is covered in Element 9
Operating procedures are covered in Elemen

t 6
Training is covered in Element 5
Mechanical integrity is covered in Element 6
Management of change is covered in Element 7
Pre-startup safety review is covered in Elements 3 and 7
Hot work permit is covered in Element 6
Contractor safety is covered in Element 8
Emergency Preparedness is covered in Element 10
Compliance audits are covered in Elements 6 and 11

Our RMP uses these individual elements to prevent accidental chemical releases.  In addition to our industry-leading management programs, we have designed state-of-the-art systems and equipment to control, prevent, detect, and mitigate potential accidental releases.  
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at BMCP. This section addresses the following elements: Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractors, Pre-startup Safety Reviews, Mechanical Integrity, Safe Work Practices, Management of Changes, Incident Investigation and Compliance Audits. 

Employee Participation
BMCP encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling operating and maintenance procedures to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to information created as part of the BMCP accident prevention program, which is documented in an employee participation plan. 

Process Safety Information
BMCP keeps a variety of documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, safe limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific groups within BMCP are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency re

sponse/exposure treatment consideration, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, BMCP has identified Operating Envelopes, i.e., documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperature, level, composition, etc. BMCP ensures that the process is maintained within these safe limits using computerized process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems, alarm systems, pressure relieving systems).

BMCP also maintains numerous documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. These documents include information such as materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis
BMCP has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. BMCP primarily uses the Knowledge-Based and Guideword Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) studies to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as a systematic and thorough hazard evaluation technique. These analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating experience and engineering expertise on the process to be evaluated. The PHA team identifies and evaluates hazards on the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures and

may make suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures.

To ensure that the process controls are consistent with design safety features, BMCP periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. In addition to these periodic reviews, hazard reviews are also performed during the design stage of new facilities and for facilities undergoing significant modification.

Operating Procedures
BMCP maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as;
(1)	startup;
(2)	normal operations; 
(3)	shutdown;
(4) 	emergency operations; and
(5) 	emergency shutdown. 

These procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a consistent basis for training of new operators. The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.

BMCP has identified Operating Envelopes, i.e., documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperature, level, and compositions. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

Training 
BMCP employees are trained to safely perform their assigned tasks. Our training program includes initial training as well as periodic refresher training and training updates when certain process or equipment changes are made. 

Training is also provided for each employee involved in maintaining the ongoing integrity of process equipment. This training includes an overview of BMCPs manufacturing process and its hazards. Training is provided on specific procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks to assure that the employees can perform the job tasks in a safe manner. Training is also provided special topics, such as the management of change (

ration of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. BMCP incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices
BMCP has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. These include orientations for visitors/contractors, control of the entry/exit of support personnel, energy isolation for equipment being worked on, procedures for the safe removal of hazardous materials before opening of process piping/equipment, hot work permit/procedure to safely manage spark-producing activities, control of vehicle entry into process area, confined space entry permit/procedure to help ensure precautions are taken before entering confined spaces, and job safety analyses to identify and mitigate hazards associated with maintenance tasks. These practices, along with related procedures and training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. 

Management of Change (MOC)
BMCP has a comprehensive system to manage changes to a process. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to:
(1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards; and,
(2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.

Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operations personnel are provided necessary training before the change is implemented.

In addition, an important tool for managing changes at BMCP is our regularly held Safe Operati

ons Committee (SOC). The SOC is a review body to ensure that high-quality, cost-effective facilities, procedures, techniques, and maintenance reduce to the minimum practical level the likelihood of personnel injury, fire or explosion, thereby ensuring a safe and reliable operation.

Incident Investigation                                                                                                                                                         BMCP promptly investigates incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental impact or personnel injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and communicates these results to BMCP management for resolution.

Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are resolved. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 (5) years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, BMCP periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. The audit team develops findings that are communicated to BMCP management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The resolution of each finding is documented, and the two (2) most recent audit reports are retained.

4.	CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 
The processes at BMCP have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The previously discus

sed general accidental release prevention program is applied to each covered process at the facility. Collectively, these prevention program activities are intended to prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors. 

In addition, BMCP utilizes safety features in and around the process operating units to aid in, (1) quickly detecting a release, (2) containing/controlling a release, and (3) reducing the consequences of (mitigating) a release. The following types of safety features are utilized in various processes:

Release Detection
- Process area detectors with alarms
- CCTV surveillance cameras

Release Containment/Control
- Process pressure relief valves that discharge to a flare system for capturing and incinerating episodic releases
- Valving to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated)
- Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)
- Curbing and/or diking to contain liquid releases
- Redundant equipment and instrumentation
- Atmospheric pressure relief devices

Release Mitigation
- Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
- Water curtain systems for specific equipment
- Trained emergency response personnel
- Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
- Blast resistant buildings to protect critical control systems and personnel

BMCP continually identifies risk reduction opportunities, including our Enhancing Process Safety (EPS) program. This program fosters sharing lessons learned broadly and actively throughout our facility. As a part of our ongoing EPS efforts, we made strides forward by eliminating chlorine from our water treatment facilities. In addition, we worked toward improving human reliability in the execution of tasks with critical steps, by using risk analyses to proactively review higher risk work for potential hazards and build key actions into procedures that our personnel

take to reduce the risk during task execution. 

5.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
BMCP had no accidents that met the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency criteria of significant equipment property damage, or resulted in harm to any individuals, or significant known adverse off-site impacts on public or environment. BMCP is committed to operating in a manner that protects the safety and health of our personnel, customers and the public, safeguards the environment and complies with applicable legal and regulatory requirements.  Our management systems foster appropriate practices and training, and require that our facilities be designed, operated and managed to prevent and/or mitigate incidents. BMCP has an excellent record of accident prevention over the life of the facility.

6.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
BMCP Emergency Response Program is outlined and managed under OIMS Element 10. The BMCP Emergency Response Program is a structured plan that is designed to provide immediate assistance and the necessary resources to effectively respond and manage incidents.  BMCP has an extensive emergency preparedness organization which includes resources from the recently integrated ExxonMobil Beaumont Refinery. The site maintains written emergency response plans at the facility, which also includes our recommended actions to ensure the safety of the community.

The key components of our Emergency Response Program are training, drills, resources, coordination, and awareness. Each of these components are outlined below: 

-	Training: Our Emergency Response Team (ERT) receives training that consists of how to respond to fires, hazardous material releases, rescue down/trapped personnel, and how to render aid to injured/hurt personnel.
-	Drills: We perform multiple drills throughout the year, which range from tabletop to actual field deployment to ensure that we can effectively respond to all types of emergency incidents.
-	Resources: We have a variety of emergency response equipment (

e.g., ambulance, fire trucks, foam tanker, boats, etc.) that are properly maintained and remains ready to respond.
-	Coordination: We are members of the Sabine Neches Chief Association (SNCA) and Jefferson Countys Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) that enable us to collaborate with our local agencies (e.g., municipal/industrial fire departments, law enforcements, hospitals, etc.) and ensure a swift and organized response. 
-	Awareness: We utilize the Southeast Texas Alert Network (STAN) system for alerting our neighbors and community of ongoing emergency incidents that may result in potential offsite impacts. 

7.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMRPOVE SAFETY                                                                                                                      
BMCP is a STAR facility in OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program. We continue to improve our safety, security, health, and environmental programs through scheduled and non-scheduled auditing and assessing. Improvement plans are developed to make the systems and the people who use them more effective. These plans are tracked to completion and validated to ensure they are effectively implemented. We conduct ongoing training and preplanning for emergencies. We steward progress of process safety and RMP prevention program elements as key performance indicators. 

Additionally, ExxonMobil's Operations Integrity Management System (OIMS) forms the cornerstone for continuous improvement in BMCPs safety-related systems to drive personnel and process safety. These systems are evergreen and are in a continuous state of improvement, usually through improvement steps such as implementation of recommendations from hazard reviews, assessments, and any incident investigations. During the period of 2020-2025, BMCP has taken significant steps to reduce the potential for incidents that could impact the surrounding community. Planned changes to enhance safety include:

(1)	Implement Personnel Safety Management System,

leveraging Loss Prevention System and Human Performance Principles; 
(2)	Enhance work permit system; and,
(3)	Continue implementing the Enhancing Process Safety (EPS) Framework.

In addition to these actions, BMCP is working to implement safety performance system updates through our continued work with EPS. The system updates are as follows:

Pressurized Storage Risk Mitigation  In 2024, as part of EPS, we completed a gas detector installation project in one of our tank farms. These safeguards were installed after risk-reducing analysis was completed and is expected to enhance incident detection and response time. Based on this analysis and our commitment to best-in-class scenario management, our Emergency Response team developed enhanced contingency planning for incident response associated with these safeguards. This work correlates with our Process Safety Future State, which puts an emphasis on critical scenarios, institutionalizes safeguard management, and utilizes drills and training to reinforce field response.
